learning_objectives: Students will understand the importance of smaller units of measurement.
Students will be able to measure objects using a scale and write their measurements in centimeters.
Students will learn to read and write lengths in fractional units.

content_blocks.text: Sonu’s mother was fixing a toy. She was trying to join two pieces with the help of a screw. Sonu was watching his mother with great curiosity. His mother was unable to join the pieces. Sonu asked why. His mother said that the screw was not of the right size. She brought another screw from the box and was able to fix the toy.
The length of the pencil shown in the figure below is 3 units, which can also be read as 3 units and four one-tenths, i.e., (3 × 1) + 4 × units.
Measure the following objects using a scale and write their measurements in centimeters (as shown earlier for the lengths of the screws): pen, sharpener, and any other object of your choice.
When exact measures are required we can make use of smaller units of measurement.
For the objects shown below, write their lengths in fractional units.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of measurement and comparison of lengths.
Students will be able to arrange lengths in increasing order.
Students will learn to convert lengths between units and tenths.

content_blocks.text: An example is given for the USB cable. (Note that the unit length used in each diagram is not the same).
Arrange these lengths in increasing order: 9 7 130 1 (a) (b) 1 (c) (d) 13 10 10 10 10 5 6 7 4 (e) 10 (f) 7 (g) 6 (h) 10 10 10 10
To get the total length, let us see the lower and upper arm length as 2 units and 7 one-tenths, and 3 units and 6 one-tenths, respectively.
So, there are (2 + 3) units and (7 + 6) one-tenths. Together, they make 5 units and 13 one-tenths.
But 13 one-tenths is 1 unit and 3 one-tenths. So, the total length is 6 units and 3 one-tenths.
Or, both the lengths can be converted to tenths and then added: (c) 2 7 one-tenths and 35 one-tenths is 62 one-tenths
The lengths of the body parts of a honeybee are given. Find its total length.
Head: 2 units 10 4 Thorax: 5 units 10 5 Abdomen: 7 units 10 4
The length of Shylaja’s hand is 12 units, 10 7 and her palm is 6 units, as shown in the picture.
What is the length of the longest (middle) finger?
The length of the finger can be found by evaluating 12 + – 6 + .
This can be done in different ways. For example, 12 units 7 10 6 units 10 4 7 (a) 12 + – 6 – 10 10 ( 4 7 ) = (12 – 6) + – 10 10 3 = 6 – 10
Discuss what is being done here and why.
As in the case of counting numbers, it is convenient to start subtraction from the tenths.
We cannot remove 7 one-tenths from 4 51 CChhaapptteerr--33..iinndddd 5511 44//1122//22002255 1111::3399::1144 AAMM Ganita Prakash | Grade 7 one-tenths.
So we split a unit from 12 and convert it to 10 one-tenths.
Now, the number has 11 units and 14 one-tenths.
We subtract 7 one-tenths from 14 one-tenths and then subtract 6 units from 11 units.
Try computing the difference by converting both lengths to tenths.
A Celestial Pearl Danio’s length is 2 cm, and the length of a Philippine 10 9 Goby is cm.
What is the difference in their lengths?
How big are these fish compared to your finger?
Observe the given sequences of numbers.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of hundredths and its relation to tenths and units.
Students will be able to convert between units, tenths, and hundredths.
Students will learn to measure lengths using hundredths.

content_blocks.text: A hundredth part is one part of a unit that is divided into 100 equal parts.
To measure lengths, we can split each one-tenth into 10 parts, making it 100 smaller parts in a unit.
If a sheet of paper is 8 9 units long, which can also be said as 10 8 units and 9 one-tenths, its length after folding in half is 4 5 units and 4 one-tenths and 5 one-hundredths.

learning_objectives: Students will understand how to read and write measurements in words.
Students will be able to identify the longest and shortest lengths in a group.
Students will learn to mark each length on a scale.

content_blocks.text: A measurement can be written in words, such as 4 units and 5 one-hundredths.
To read a measurement, we need to identify the units, tenths, and hundredths.
The length of the wire in the first picture is given as 1 4 1, which can also be written as one and one-tenth and four-hundredths.

learning_objectives: Students will understand how to add numbers.
Students will be able to solve addition problems using different methods.
Students will learn to identify the sum of two numbers.

content_blocks.text: Addition is the process of finding the sum of two or more numbers.
We can solve addition problems using different methods, such as the column method or the place value method.
The sum of 15 and 2 can be solved using the column method: (15 + 2) + + + + 10 10 100 100 10

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimal place value and its importance in measurement.
Students will be able to convert between different place values, such as tenths and hundredths.
Students will learn to represent numbers in decimal form and understand the relationship between decimal and fraction forms.

content_blocks.text: Decimal place value is the value of a digit in a decimal number based on its position. The position of a digit in a decimal number determines its place value.
When we need to measure something more accurately, we split a part into 10 equal parts. This is because 10 plays a special role in the Indian place value system.
For example, if we split a unit into 10 equal parts, each part is called a tenth. If we split each tenth into 10 equal parts, each part is called a hundredth.
We can also split a unit into 4 equal parts, 5 equal parts, or any other number of equal parts. However, the Indian place value system uses 10 as the base for its place value system.
If an even more precise measure is needed, each quarter can further be split into four equal parts. Each 1 part then measures of a unit, i.e., 16 such parts make 1 unit.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of place value and its importance in the decimal system.
Students will be able to extend the decimal system to quantities smaller than one.
Students will learn to represent numbers in the decimal system using place value notation.

content_blocks.text: Each place value is 10 times bigger than the one immediately to its right. Equivalently, each place value is 10 times smaller than the one immediately to its left: 10 ones make 1 ten, 10 tens make 1 hundred, 10 hundreds make 1 thousand, and so on.

In order to extend this system of writing numbers to quantities smaller than one, we divide one into 10 equal parts. What does this give? It gives one-tenth. Further dividing it into 10 parts gives one-hundredth, and so on.
What will the fraction be when is split into 10 equal parts? 100 1 It will be , i.e., a thousand such parts make up a unit. 1000
Just as when we extend to the left of 10,000, we get bigger place values at each step, we can also extend to the right of , getting smaller place values at each step.

This way of writing numbers is called the “decimal system” since it is based on the number 10; “decem” means ten in Latin, which in turn is cognate to the Sanskrit daśha meaning 10, with similar words for 10 occurring across many Indian languages including Odia, Konkani, Marathi, Gujarati, Hindi, Kashmiri, Bodo, and Assamese.
We shall learn about other ways of writing numbers in later grades.

We already know that a hundred 10s make 1000, and a hundred 100s make 10000. We can ask similar questions about fractional parts: (a) How many thousandths make one unit? (b) How many thousandths make one tenth? (c) How many thousandths make one hundredth? (d) How many tenths make one ten? (e) How many hundredths make one ten? Make a few more questions of this kind and answer them.
We have been writing numbers in a particular way, say 456, instead of writing them as 4 × 100 (4 hundreds) + 5 × 10 (5 tens) + 6 × 1 (6 ones). Similarly, can we skip writing tenths and hundredths?
Math Can the quantity 4 be written as 42 skipping the in 2 × ? Talk 10 10 10 If yes, how would we know if 42 means 4 tens and 2 units or it means 4 units and 2 tenths?
Since these are different quantities, we need to have distinct ways

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimal notation and its application in representing numbers with fractional parts.
Students will be able to convert numbers from decimal notation to place value and vice versa.
Students will learn to read and write numbers in decimal notation.

content_blocks.text: Decimal notation is a natural extension of the Indian place value system to numbers also having fractional parts.
To identify the place value where integers end and the fractional parts start, we use a point or period (‘.’) as a separator, called a decimal point.
The number 70.5 means 7 × 10 + 5 × , and 7.05 means 10 1 7 × 1 +5 × .

We know that 705 is read as seven hundred and five, 70.5 is read as seventy point five, short for seventy and five-tenths, and 7.05 is read as seven point zero five, short for seven and five hundredths.
Make a place value table similar to the one above. Write each quantity in decimal form and in terms of place value, and read the number: (a) 2 ones, 3 tenths and 5 hundredths

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of units of measurement and their conversion.
Students will be able to convert between different units of measurement.
Students will learn to apply units of measurement in real-life situations.

content_blocks.text: We have been using a scale to measure length for a few years.
We already know that 1 cm = 10 mm (millimeters).
How many cm is 1 mm? 1 1 mm = cm = 0.1 cm (i.e., one-tenth of a cm).
5 5 mm = cm = 0.5 cm
12 mm = 10 mm + 2 mm 2 = 1 cm + cm 10 = 1.2 cm.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of unit conversion and its importance.
Students will be able to convert units of length and weight from one system to another.
Students will learn to apply unit conversion in real-life situations.
Students will understand the concept of conversion of units and its importance.
Students will be able to convert units of mass and currency.
Students will learn to apply conversion of units in real-life situations.

content_blocks.text: Unit conversion is the process of changing the unit of measurement of a quantity from one system to another.
To convert units of length, we can use the conversion factors such as 1 m = 100 cm, 1 cm = 0.01 m, etc.
Example: Convert 10 cm to meters. Since 1 cm = 0.01 m, we can write 10 cm = 10 x 0.01 m = 0.1 m.
To convert units of weight, we can use the conversion factors such as 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 g = 0.001 kg, etc.
We can also use the conversion factors to convert units of weight from one system to another.
Example: Convert 5 g to kilograms. Since 1 g = 0.001 kg, we can write 5 g = 5 x 0.001 kg = 0.005 kg.
100 paise is equal to 1 rupee. As we have coins and notes for rupees, coins for paise were also used commonly until recently.
1 rupee = 100 paise, 1 paisa = 0.01 rupee

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of measurement of small things.
Students will be able to measure small things using different units.
Students will learn to apply measurement of small things in real-life situations.

content_blocks.text: Measurement of small things is the process of measuring the length or weight of small objects.
We can measure small things using different units such as millimeters, centimeters, grams, etc.
Example: Measure the length of a human hair using a ruler. The length of a human hair is typically around 0.1 mm.
We can also measure the weight of small things using a balance or a scale.
We can use the conversion factors to convert units of measurement from one system to another.
Example: Convert 1 mm to centimeters. Since 1 cm = 10 mm, we can write 1 mm = 0.1 cm.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimals and its representation.
Students will be able to identify and write decimal numbers.
Students will learn to compare and order decimal numbers.
Students will understand the concept of decimals and their representation.
Students will be able to add and subtract decimals using standard procedures.
Students will learn to estimate sums and differences of decimal numbers.
allowed_concepts: standard procedure for adding and subtracting decimals

content_blocks.text: 1.4 lies between 1 and 2. Draw the number line and divide the unit between 1 and 2 into 10 equal parts.
1.4 is equal to 1 unit and 4 tenths. This means that the unit between 1 and 2 is divided into 10 equal parts, and 4 such parts are taken.
0.2, 0.20, and 0.200 are all equal as they represent the same quantity, i.e., 2 tenths.
total quantity of cloth needed is 6.2 m.
We have to find the difference of 3.5m – 2.7m.
Again, observe how 5 7 the differences 3 – 2 and 3.5m – 2.7m are computed.
As you can see, the standard procedure for adding and subtracting whole numbers can be used to add and subtract decimals.
A detailed view of the underlying place value calculation is shown below for the sum 75.345 + 86.691.
Its compact form is shown next to it.
Decimal Sequences Observe this sequence of decimal numbers and identify the change after each term. 4.4, 4.8. 5.2, 5.6, 6.0, …
We can see that 0.4 is being added to a term to get the next term.
Continue this sequence and write the next 3 terms.
Similarly, identify the change and write the next 3 terms for each sequence given below.
Try to do this computation mentally.
Make your own sequences and challenge your classmates to extend the pattern.

Estimating Sums and Differences Sonu has observed sums and differences of decimal numbers and says, “If we add two decimal numbers, then the sum will always be greater than the sum of their whole number parts.
Also, the sum will always be less than 2 more than the sum of their whole number parts.”
Let us use an example to understand what his claim means:
If the two numbers to be added are 25.936 and 8.202, the claim is that their sum will be greater than 25 + 8 (whole number parts) and will be less than 25 + 1 + 8 + 1.
What do you think about this claim?
Verify if this is true for these Math numbers.
Will it work for any 2 decimal numbers?
Talk What about for the sum of 25.93603259 and 8.202?
Similarly, come up with a way to narrow down the range of whole Try numbers within which the difference of two decimal numbers This will lie.
Note to the Teacher: Estimating the result before computing may help in identifying if a mistake

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimal numbers and their representation on the number line.
Students will be able to compare decimal numbers using the number line and place value.
Students will learn to add and subtract decimal numbers.

content_blocks.text: Decimal numbers are numbers that have a decimal point and are used to represent fractions or parts of a whole.
To compare decimal numbers, we can use the number line and compare the place value of each digit.

For example, to compare 6.456 and 6.465, we can see that they have the same place value for the units and tenths, but the first number has only 5 hundredths, whereas the second number has 6 hundredths.
To add decimal numbers, we can add the corresponding digits in each place value, just like we do with whole numbers.
For example, to add 2.7m and 3.5m, we can add the corresponding digits in each place value: 2.7 + 3.5 = 6.2.
To subtract decimal numbers, we can subtract the corresponding digits in each place value, just like we do with whole numbers.
For example, to subtract 3.5m from 2.7m, we can subtract the corresponding digits in each place value: 2.7 - 3.5 = -0.8.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the importance of decimal notation and its applications.
Students will be able to convert between decimal and fraction forms.
Students will learn to identify and correct decimal errors.

content_blocks.text: Decimal fractions (i.e., fractions with denominators like 10, 100, 1000, and so on) are used in the works of a number of ancient Indian astronomers and mathematicians, including in the important 8th century works of Śhrīdharāchārya on arithmetic and algebra.

Decimal notation, in essentially its modern form, was described in detail in Kitāb al-Fuṣūl fī al-Ḥisāb al Hindī (The Book of Chapters on Indian Arithmetic) by Abūl Ḥassan al-Uqlīdisī, an Arab mathematician.
For example, reading 0.05 mg as 0.5 mg can lead to using a medicine 10 times more than the prescribed quantity.
Here, 0.5 hours means splitting an hour into 10 equal parts and taking 5 parts out of it. Each part will be 6 minutes (60 minutes/10) long. 5 such parts make 30 minutes.

A girl measures the width of an opening as 2 ft 5 inches but conveys to the carpenter to make a door 2.5 ft wide. The carpenter makes a door of width 2 ft 6 inches (since 1 ft = 12 inches, 0.5 ft = 6 inches), and it wouldn’t close fully.

A Pinch of History – Decimal Notation Over Time 1 1 Decimal fractions (i.e., fractions with denominators like , , 10 100 1 , and so on) are used in the works of a number of ancient Indian 1000 astronomers and mathematicians, including in the important 8th century works of Śhrīdharāchārya on arithmetic and algebra.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimals and fractions.
Students will be able to convert fractions into decimals and vice versa.
Students will learn to compare and order decimals and fractions.
Students will be able to convert between decimals and fractions.
Students will be able to convert fractions to decimals and vice versa.
allowed_concepts: comparing and ordering decimals and fractions

content_blocks.text: A decimal number is a number that has a whole number part and a fractional part separated by a decimal point.
To convert a fraction into a decimal, we divide the numerator by the denominator.
Convert the fraction 1/2 into a decimal: 1 ÷ 2 = 0.5
To convert a decimal into a fraction, we can write it as a division problem.
Convert the decimal 0.5 into a fraction: 0.5 = 1/2
To compare and order decimals and fractions, we can use the concept of place value.
Compare the decimals 0.5 and 0.6: 0.5 < 0.6
Can we write 1 mm = m?

Decimals are numbers that have a fractional part, which is represented by a dot (.) followed by one or more digits.
To convert a fraction into a decimal, we divide the numerator by the denominator. For example, 1/2 = 0.5, 1/4 = 0.25, and 3/4 = 0.75.
Convert the following fractions into decimals: 5/16 = 0.3125, 12/25 = 0.48, 2/5 = 0.4

To compare decimals, we can look at the digits after the decimal point. If the digits are the same, we can look at the next digit to the right. If the digits are different, we can compare them directly.
Compare the following decimals: 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5
To order decimals, we can compare them using the same method as comparing fractions.
Order the following decimals: 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5

quantities mentioned (an example is given): (a) 87 ones, 5 tenths and 60 hundredths (b) 12 tens and 12 tenths (c) 10 tens, 10 ones, 10 tenths, and 10 hundredths (d) 25 tens, 25 ones, 25 tenths, and 25 hundredths
Ans: 19 (a) 88.10 121.2 (b) 111.1 277.75 15. Using each digit 0 – 9 not more than once, fill the boxes below so that the sum is closest to 10.5: Ans: 16.

topic_name: Converting Decimals to Tenths, Hundredths, and Thousandths
learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of converting decimals to tenths, hundredths, and thousandths.
Students will be able to convert decimals to tenths, hundredths, and thousandths.
Students will learn to write decimals as a sum of tenths, hundredths, and thousandths.
Students will learn to compare and order decimals in tenths, hundredths, and thousandths.
allowed_concepts: comparing decimals in tenths, hundredths, and thousandths

content_blocks.text: Tenths, hundredths, and thousandths are the parts of a decimal number.
To convert a decimal to tenths, hundredths, and thousandths, we can use the concept of place value.
Convert the decimal 0.34 to tenths, hundredths, and thousandths: 0.34 = 34/100 = 3/10 + 4/100
To convert a decimal to tenths, we can move the decimal point one place to the right and add a zero after the decimal point.
To convert a decimal to hundredths, we can move the decimal point two places to the right and add two zeros after the decimal point.
Convert the following decimals to tenths: 0.5 = 5/10, 0.25 = 2.5/10, 0.75 = 7.5/10
To convert a decimal to thousandths, we can move the decimal point three places to the right and add three zeros after the decimal point.
Convert the following decimals to thousandths: 0.5 = 500/1000, 0.25 = 250/1000, 0.75 = 750/1000
To compare decimals in tenths, hundredths, and thousandths, we can look at the digits after the decimal point.
Compare the following decimals: 0.5, 0.25, 0.75

topic_name: Comparing and Ordering Decimals and Fractions
learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of comparing and ordering decimals and fractions.
Students will be able to compare and order decimals and fractions.
Students will learn to use the concept of place value to compare and order decimals and fractions.

content_blocks.text: To compare and order decimals and fractions, we can use the concept of place value.
We can compare and order decimals and fractions by looking at the place value of the digits.
Compare the decimals 0.5 and 0.6: 0.5 < 0.6

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of decimals and place value.
Students will be able to convert between decimals and fractions.
Students will learn to compare and order decimal numbers.

content_blocks.text: We can split a unit into smaller parts to get more exact/accurate measurements.

We extended the Indian place value system and saw that » 1 unit = 10 one-tenths, » 1 tenth = 10 one-hundredths, » 1 hundredth = 10 one-thousandths, » 10 one-hundredths = 1 tenth, » 100 one-hundredths = 1 unit.
87 ones, 5 tenths and 60 hundredths = 88.10
A decimal point (‘.’) is used in the Indian place value system to separate the whole number part of a number from its fractional part.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of comparing and ordering decimals.
Students will be able to compare and order decimals.
Students will learn to use the concept of place value to compare and order decimals.

content_blocks.text: To compare decimals, we can look at the digits after the decimal point.
To order decimals, we can compare them using the same method as comparing fractions.
Compare the following decimals: 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5
To use the concept of place value to compare and order decimals, we can look at the digits after the decimal point and compare them directly.
Compare the following decimals: 0.5, 0.25, 0.75

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of converting decimals to fractions.
Students will be able to convert decimals to fractions.
Students will learn to use the concept of place value to convert decimals to fractions.

content_blocks.text: To convert a decimal to a fraction, we can divide the numerator by the denominator.
To use the concept of place value to convert decimals to fractions, we can look at the digits after the decimal point and compare them directly.
Convert the following decimals to fractions: 0.5 = 1/2, 0.25 = 1/4, 0.75 = 3/4

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of real-world applications of decimals.
Students will be able to apply decimals to real-world situations.
Students will learn to use decimals to solve problems in real-world situations.

content_blocks.text: Decimals are used in real-world situations to represent quantities that are not whole numbers.
To apply decimals to real-world situations, we can use them to solve problems that involve quantities that are not whole numbers.
A book costs $12.50. If we want to buy 5 books, how much will we pay in total?
To use decimals to solve problems, we can use them to represent quantities that are not whole numbers.
A car travels 25.6 kilometers in 4 hours. What is its average speed?
